newsitem.title: USA: Gap reports higher third quarter profits.
newsitem.headline: Gap reports higher third quarter profits.

text.p: Gap Inc. Thursday reported a 15 percent jump in third-quarter profits, reflecting strong sales in all three of its retail chains.

The company, which operates Gap, Banana Republic and Old Navy stores, said profits rose to $134.3 million, or 48 cents a share, in the quarter ended on Nov. 2, from $116.9 million, or 41 cents a share, in the 1995 quarter. Sales rose 20 percent to $1.38 billion from $1.16 billion.
Sales at stores open for more than one year rose 1 percent in the quarter.

"Our third quarter results are a tribute to the balance we have in our businesses," said Millard Drexler, president and chief executive officer. "Each of these brands -- Gap, Banana Republic, and Old Navy -- contributed to total sales growth, with exceptional results at Old Navy, leading to our record third quarter earnings."

Earnings for the first nine months of the fiscal year grew 41 percent to $281.7 million, or 99 cents a share, from $199.4 million, or 69 cents a share, last year. Net sales grew 26 percent to $3.62 billion from $2.87 billion.
Gap operated 1,823 stores as of Nov. 2, including 935 Gap stores, 222 Banana Republic stores, 486 GapKids stores and 180 Old Navy stores.
Gap stock fell 50 cents to $31.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
